Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: MSB-FRA: Causes, consequences, and cross-scale linkages of environment-driven phenological mismatch across three trophic levels
Award.AbstractNarration:
The timing and synchrony of seasonal events presents real challenges in the natural world. Migratory birds coordinate their departure from wintering grounds in Central or South America to arrive at North American breeding grounds at just the right time. Too early and they risk experiencing severe weather from late frosts or blizzards. Too late and they risk missing the peak in early spring insects that they depend on to successfully raise offspring. For their part, insects such as butterflies also benefit when their emergence coincides with the springtime flush of new plant growth. The timing of spring has been shifting earlier in recent years, and this raises the possibility of mismatches in spring timing between birds, insects, and plants. A few local scale studies have suggested that such mismatches may be responsible for long-term population declines for some species, but the extent of this problem, especially over large areas remains unknown. In this project, the research team will combine information on springtime weather, satellite imagery on plant emergence, and multiple large-scale citizen science data on birds, butterflies, and caterpillars to perform a comprehensive evaluation of mismatches in seasonal timing between interacting species. This work is critical for understanding the potential impacts of continued shifts in seasonality on living systems. The work will also engage K-college students and the public through a new citizen science program, educational units, and outreach events focused on learning about the timing of seasonal changes.

The proposed research will be the first attempt to examine phenological mismatch across three trophic levels at a semi-continental extent. Local-scale studies have documented specific instances of phenological mismatch but fail to inform how mismatch consequences propagate across spatial, temporal, or trophic scales. Birds and butterflies provide the most expansive, long-term and detailed macroecological data sets on distribution, diversity, and demography. The project will unite multiple large-scale citizen science datasets for these taxa with targeted field data collection, and remotely-sensed climate and vegetation data layers, to examine the cross-scale and multi-trophic interactions that connect shifting thermal environments, phenological mismatch, and fitness consequences. This will be accomplished by: (1) assembling and uniting continental and regional monitoring and citizen-science databases for Lepidoptera and birds; (2) building spatio-temporal models in order to assess drivers of phenology, calculate direct metrics of phenological mismatch across trophic levels, and evaluate fitness and population consequences of those mismatches; and (3) testing the ability of generated models to predict phenology and population trends for focal birds and Lepidoptera across eastern North America as a function of tri-trophic phenological mismatch. Taking a macro-scale perspective on phenological mismatch is critical for understanding the range-wide impacts of sustained trends in seasonal timing. In addition to answering critical research questions on phenological mismatch the team will extend the impacts of their work through both specific training opportunities and broad-based education and outreach efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on how climate is shifting the timing of ecological events such as emergence of plants, insects, and migratory birds. While the field of climate change ecology has focused mostly on species’ range shifts, there has been comparatively less focus on how changes of days or weeks in seasonal timing can influence species, communities, and ecosystems. Recently, this phenological research has shifted to focus on how differential emergence timing may cause phenological “mismatches” (e.g., between plants, insects, and insectivorous birds). If, for example, insects shifted earlier in warmer springs, but plants did not, then those insects may emerge in a world with nothing to eat. This could depress insect populations which could impact the ability of migratory birds to successfully rear offspring during the summer breeding season. The vast majority of phenological mismatch studies to date use on-the-ground data collection which is extremely valuable but necessarily occurs over small spaces and short time periods. The goal of our project was to scale up these trophic interactions and determine how they play out across a larger scale. This work necessitated a highly collaborative and multi-disciplinary group of researchers. This summary covers the collective achievements of the UCLA-based team, but please see additional outcomes of our collaborators (e.g., associated NSF awards 1702664 and 1702708).

Our results highlight the immense complexity of how seasonal ecological events interact and relate to each other. The field of climate change impacts has largely focused on species shifting their distributions across space, with comparatively less focus on how changes of days or weeks in seasonal timing can influence species, communities, and ecosystems. Our published work has demonstrated a novel conceptual link between range shifts and phenological shifts in birds, and between phenology, demography, and environmental gradients. Our grant culminated in a demonstration of how bird and lepidopteran species’ traits can strongly define the spectrum of risk to phenological mismatch, while illustrating how phenological shifts and their demographic consequences propagate through space, over time, and across trophic levels. Additionally, this grant supported numerous methodological and computational advances, leading to publications on topics including how to monitor insects, where citizen science data are biased, and how to quantify phenology and phenological shifts.

This project had numerous impacts broader than scientific advancement. For example, it provided training and hands-on analysis opportunities to dozens of undergraduates, 7 graduate students, and 3 postdocs, many of whom hold backgrounds underrepresented in science. We also published a teaching case study on phenological mismatch with the National Center for Case Study Teaching in Science, which provides a resource for teachers to integrate real-world research into their teaching. In terms of informational infrastructure, the grant supported the verification of and public access to data from a vital continent-wide monitoring program of bird demography that is already being used broadly by other scientists. Finally, scientists involved in this project disseminated their results widely, tallying over 50 academic lectures, 13 public talks, and 29 media interviews. Results deriving from this grant were incorporated into the production of a PBS television program on spring phenology that reached approximately 3.7 million live viewers.
